conversation.content:
[bitter] Thirty-two years. Thirty-two years I've run this place, and now they want to shut me down just when I was— [sigh] God, the timing couldn't be worse. [frustrated] I had everything planned out, you know? The vocational training, the, um... the partnerships with local businesses who'd actually hire the girls. [very sad] Maria was going to start her nursing program next month. [pause] Next month! And Sasha, she was so excited about the bookkeeping course, she'd already bought her textbooks and... [trailing off] 

[angry] They think we're just criminals here, but these women, they're— [short pause] I've watched them grow, helped them through, err... through things that would break most people. [passionately] And I was finally going to help them get out properly, with actual skills, with dignity! [cry] Not just thrown onto the street with nothing. 

[shaky voice] Twenty thousand dollars I'd saved for this transition program. [laugh bitterly] My own retirement money, basically. Because I knew this day would come eventually, I just thought... hmm, I thought I'd have more time. [very quietly] I promised them I'd take care of them. [sniffle] How do I tell them that tomorrow we're just... done?

subject: The madam business you've run for decades being shut down just as you were planning to help your workers transition to new careers
